An evening with Graham Norton review, York Theatre Royal

12/10/2022

Alanah Hammond listens to Graham Norton in conversation with Konnie Huq on his book tour for Forever Home

Image by York Theatre Royal

By Alanah Hammond

York Theatre Royal promised an evening with Graham Norton, and after severe train delays which meant that his interviewer Konnie Huq couldnâ€™t make it until the second half, we were well acquainted with the BAFTA winning TV presenter by the end of the night.

I too was unfortunate enough to get stuck in London on Monday afternoon, however, I made it back to York, after waiting in Kings Cross for four hours, in time for Grahamâ€™s show â€“ which was delightful.

After a delayed start, with the show being pushed back to 7:45pm, perhaps the audience needed warming up as the first two questions were fairly rubbish. Graham was asked whether he had received books and cakes back-stage, but after being dashed from London to York in a car, how could he have had time to explore any dressing room gifts? However, Graham answered graciously and swiftly moved onto the next.

As our confidence grew, the questions sparked some more interesting replies. Favourite guest? Miriam Margolyes is always great. Worst guest? Harvey Weinstein, of course. Now, in retrospect, Graham saw his â€œpredatoryâ€ behaviour. Guests which Graham would like next? Brad Pitt, Julia Roberts or the young Royals.

We even jumped the gun, asking about his writing without Konnie. Graham explained how he wanted to write a novel for a long time, and it got to the point where you either do it or shut up about it. He chose the former, explaining how writing was something for the â€œgreat 50 and beyondâ€ because once you hit that age everything just â€œskids down into a deep dark holeâ€.

Eurovision was our next choice of subject, to which Graham explained that the â€œvibes were rightâ€. Sam Ryder was â€œfantastic, and a great ambassadorâ€. He also discussed Ukraineâ€™s win through the popular vote: â€œItâ€™s a camp, stupid singing competition but every now and then it does something right. [Ukraineâ€™s win] was not political with a capital P, but it was like youâ€™re in a war and weâ€™re here for youâ€. He also admitted that he would not be revealing where Eurovision 2023 would be held, and that we would have to wait till Friday. We can now reveal that it will be held in Liverpool!

The audience then asked what Grahamâ€™s best decision was, but before he could answer, one keen participant shouted, â€œgetting marriedâ€ to which Graham crudely replied, â€œthank god youâ€™re here!â€. Graham saw a great comedic opportunity, explaining that his wedding was indeed memorable. For example, vows such as â€œtill death do us partâ€ seem more achievable at 50, rather than at 20.

Graham also detailed his wedding reception held in West Cork, in Bantry, where funny rumours arose that Elton John was spotted in the local pub, whereas Adele without makeup was seen in SuperValu, the local chain store, which Graham described as â€œessentially every woman in the shopâ€.

Our last questions quizzed Graham over his beard and whether it was here to stay. Sharply, Graham replied, â€œhas my mother got to you?â€ and said, like fine wine, he thought it made him look better with age. We then heard his very funny, and rather intimate, Red Chair story involving his dog, a gentleman caller and a lost protection product. We also found out that no, he doesnâ€™t like to re-watch his shows, since he is saving them for retirement.

With Konnie now on stage, the second half of the show started with a reading from Grahamâ€™s latest novel Forever Home. The audience learned from Konnieâ€™s interview that Graham has a trope within his books of someone finding something, which leads to a repercussion. Now we were even more intrigued.

Graham also explained his writing is inspired from living in Ireland in the 70s, his mother and liking novels with plot. Specifically, Graham recalled rural Ireland. He described it as a place in which people live just outside the village, allowing folk to have some secrets. These secrets, he explained, are perfect as a springboard for his writing.

Every writer can suffer with deadline issues, so Graham revealed he gives himself a year, from April to April, to write his books. He also expanded on why he decided to start writing books. He revealed he likes the solitude of writing, and when he thought about his worst-case scenario, of his novel being a flop and going back to solely TV presenting, it wasnâ€™t really all that bad.

For his first time in York, Graham certainly made quite the impression on us. His latest novel sounds gripping and well thought-out, and with a personality like his, which we sampled throughout the whole evening, I am sure it is as good as it sounds. Until next April!
